title: How many pages should I read a day? - Quora

response.answer_text: Generally, there’s no need to set quotas for reading, unless you’re doing coursework or something like that, where there are time limits imposed from the outside. Then you need to schedule your own time based on how much reading there is and how fast you read. But I think you will be best served if you switch from focusing on quantity of reading to focusing on quality. This has 2 aspects: the quality of the things you readthe quality of your readingIf you’re trying to get more out of your reading, one approach is to read better things. As for what counts as “better,” that’s somewhat up to you. If we’re talking about nonfiction, it might mean reading more scholarly or in-depth works on a particular subject, or maybe reading more books on that subject rather than just one (if the subject is of interest to you). If we’re talking about fiction, it might mean reading works that challenge you more: classics, literary fiction, or general fiction that is outside the genre categories you usually read. As for the quality of your actual reading, how well you read, I’d like to recommend the book How to Read a Book (ISBN 9780671212094) by Mortimer J. Adler and Charles Van Doren, first published in 1940. It’s an excellent guide, but its focus is mainly on nonfiction. I haven’t found anything comparable for fiction reading, but if you’re willing to put on your thinking cap and have your mind expanded very far, then try Anatomy of Criticism: Four Essays (ISBN 0691012989) by Northrop Frye. He looks at literature in great depth. Another interesting one is How to Read and Why (ISBN 0684859076) by Harold Bloom; he loves literature, and helps the reader love it more too. I love reading and I read for hours each day, but I don’t really worry about how many pages I read. For me, the important thing is enjoyment and whether I’m absorbing what I’m reading. So I will read a book for as long as I’m enjoying it and absorbing what I’m reading. When my attention starts to flag I’ll put that book aside, and pick up another one. When I don’t feel like picking up another book, my reading period is over. You’re far better off choosing one really good book, and reading it carefully, than reading 100 mediocre books. With reading, as with so much else in life, quality is king. That’s the way to get the most out of reading, in my opinion.

For my ENGH 305 class, we read 100 pages or fewer for Wednesday’s class and over 100 pages for Monday’s class until we’re finished with the novel(s) For my other classes, we just read articles and/or the textbook(s), which can be short or lengthy, simple or complex. The extraction of quotations has to happen at some point in most of my classes. (In ENGH 301, we also read a lot of pages per class period. Usually we finished the book within 2–3 weeks, even though we met once per week.) Then, we have lots of reflections, participation discussions, group projects, peer reviews, and essays. I’m neither done taking exams nor am I done with multiple choice (I’ll have to do that for my history courses I bet, as well as the VCLA and Praxis). I read my once-a-month murder mystery in under a week. I try to aim for about 100 pages daily for those, too, yet I might go over if I want to finish earlier. Then, I write simple summaries and interesting facts from the novel. This is my current list (published) of books/writings I’ve read as of my Fall 2020 semester. I will not be adding more books to this list, since it’s time-consuming. I will only be updating my list for records’ sake.
